rComments: Professor Allina is an expert in his field, and handles the most difficult subjects with grace and professionalism. Evaluations aren't always clear, and you need to read and participate a lot, but if you genuinely want to learn about African history, take him. His passion is contagious, and reminds me why I went into history in the first place.

He is amazing! Very clear in his lectures and loves when you ask questions. He is passionate about his subject but the readings he gives out are very long but very interesting. The readings are needed for his quizzes which can be worded weirdly but if you ask for help you should be fine.

Professor Allina is fantastic. I have now taken two of his courses and it is very clear on what he expects. Do the readings and you'll be fine for the weekly quizzes. Put in the work and you'll get a good grade, slack and you won't. I will continue to look out for his name in courses I take.
teacherRatingTags: ['Amazing lectures ', 'Clear grading criteria', 'Get ready to read']

rComments: This had the potential to be an enjoyable class, but the weekly quizzes worth 30% of your grade overall were extremely difficult. I spent more time on them than anything else and I had to stop doing the readings before class because I knew I would have to read them three-times again when the quiz was released. Too many presentations.

A good lecturer, classes were interesting. There's a LOT of readings and they are all pretty dense, and you need to read all of them to do well. His quizzes were open book and not timed, but they were VERY time-consuming and pretty hard, and you don't get a lot of feedback. No other assignments other the quizzes though, even the final was optional.

He is super nice and chill, but he gives way to many quizzes on stuff which take at least 2 hours of serious work and then is super tough on grading. I would not recommend this class; though it has interesting components, the lessons are long and not always interesting. He gives a ton of reading to do, which ends up being useless.

I took two classes with Allina and he's absolutely one of my favourite profs at uOttawa. His classes are fascinating, and he really forces you to engage the material and THINK. His seminar was pretty tough, but I learned so much; the man helped me grow as a scholar and supported me the whole way. Would 100% take another class with him.

He is a really great prof who is really passionnate and knowlegable about his subject. Tougher grader, but always there to answer questions. Definitely will be taking him again. Yes, there is a lot of reading, but every text is actually relevant to the course, so it's worth your time. Work hard, take lots of notes, and you'll have a good time.

just finished the Slavery module and BOY this guy was amazing! His lectures are so clear , but at the same time, no TOO much info at once. Do the readings, but he lightly touches on them in his lectures. Course work is light, 2 assignments per module. no midterm. He treats you like you're paying $7000, as opposed to as a number! Who knew?
he's hard

I thought that Professor Allina was friendly, but as a second language student, I felt his French (which is clearly not his first language either) was not always understandable. I feel I would have enjoyed his class more if he taught in English

Just a really nice guy who clearly knows what he's talking about and is always helpful to students. He's funny and encourages discussion, I don't have any complaints about him. He assigns reading but it's not really *required* so to say, just helps.

Eric Allina is one of the best history Professors at the University of Ottawa. His lectures are engaging and full of discussion. The lectures are to help you analyze the readings and how they pertain to the course material. Allina wants his students to succeed, and encourages you to ask for help when needed. He is friendly, sarcastic, and funny.

It was a tough class which you had work really hard for. Professor Allina is a smart guy and makes you think really hard. Some of the readings we covered were great, whilst others were dry. Unfortunately there was not much feedback provided on assignments. But it seems like he is the best option for HIS2100.

Very focused on readings and participation, he will most likely learn your name. The content is fairly dry, depending on how much you enjoy the readings, so the lectures may drag on. He is also a tough marker, but definitely a friendly professor, and I enjoyed his class overall.

Prof Allina provides good constructive criticism if you email or see him during office hours. But, still he's extremely tough when it comes to marking written work. You have to genuinely want to work hard on your writing skills or else you'll end up with a really low mark. Classes are mostly discussion and participation is 10%.
teacherRatingTags: ['So many papers', 'Tough grader', 'Get ready to read']

rComments: Professor Allina talks and talks and talks and demands students to respond and make conversation. This would be fine if the subject matter wasn't already common sense (understanding all historians have bias). I'm great at essays (avg 80s in all classes) and he makrs hard with a 60. Read the readings or go to class, you don't need both. Avoid.

I really like Prof. Allina. My class was large (still small compared to my others however) and he still took the time to learn our names. You do have to read alot for this course but you discuss the readings so it's basically madatory. He can be a little vague with his instructions with assignments but just send him an email and he'll answer
teacherRatingTags: ['Tough grader', 'Gives good feedback', 'Get ready to read']

rComments: Prof Allina is a stellar professor who knows how to teach! Having studied at Ivy League schools, he might seem intimidating to some students but will be there to help if you show interest in his class. Readings were long and challenging. The format of the class was: participation, midterm, research essay and outline and take home final exam.

I was really excited on the first day of class and then rapidly became disappointed. He asked us to email him questions and responses, so I put a lot of effort into mine and he never once answered me. He chooses random, trivial events from the (terrible) textbook for the quizzes. We had to learn every single country in Africa in less than a week.
Always prepared for class. Great guy, but there were SO MANY READINGS. This is a second year class and he treated it more like a 4th year seminar. Not much posted online
teacherRatingTags: ['Gives good feedback', 'Participation matters', 'Get ready to read']

rComments: Brilliant professor, and makes a seemingly boring class incredibly interesting. You have to keep up with the readings to understand the lectures and receive a good grade.
Oh goodness. Readings galore. Hard exams, etc....
teacherRatingTags: ['Gives good feedback', 'Get ready to read', 'Tough grader']

rComments: Professor Allina is always well prepared for class, and he did an excellent job of providing an over-arching narrative which tied class readings together.
Great Professor! You really need to do the readings, and definitely have to work for your marks, but it is worth it. Really wants his students to succeed :)
Very interesting, very engaging. You need to do your readings, but he makes a discussion out of it. Super helpful and incredibly passionate. Would recommend him to anyone.
Phenomenal.
great teacher and helps his immersion students! very educated!

He is a really great professor who is passionate about his field. He asks really complex and mind-boggling questions every class, but that is the purpose of university right? He is really kind and helpful. Your paradigm of history will totally change after taking this class! Fair grader and provides great feedback. Very historiographic oriented.
